image.altText: Court hammer and judge in background

items.synopsis: Lies, threats and manipulation — how recordings exposed a rogue expert witness, in a case legal practitioners say is the tip of the iceberg.

title.children: Lies, threats and manipulation: The recordings exposing a court psychologist at work

image.altText: An e-scooter with helmet attached stands upright in front of a council building

items.synopsis: The City of Darwin wants to improve infrastructure, including adding more bike lines, electric charging stations, and e-scooter parking spots across the city to make it easier for people to use e-scooters to commute.

title.children: As e-scooter tech rapidly advances, Darwin's council is reviewing the role they play in transport

image.altText: RBA governor Philip Lowe speaks at the Morgan Stanley Australia summit in Sydney

items.synopsis: Price caps on gas and energy bill subsidies may be lowering inflation. Can we do more things like that, instead of just raising interest rates?

title.children: Economists tell how to lower inflation without raising interest rates

image.altText: Alexandra Collier, with red lipstick, slight smile, and floral shirt, faces camera in close shot.

items.synopsis: The number of people choosing to start a family on their own is on the rise in Australia. Meet two women who followed different paths into solo parenthood.

title.children: 'I left a very good and happy relationship.' Alexandra's partner didn't want a baby, so she did it alone

image.altText: A female ringer walks towards cattle.

items.synopsis: Farmers need workers, and thanks to TikTok and Instagram many are emerging wanting to be a ringer, spending their days mustering cattle in dusty paddocks under wide-open skies.

title.children: It's not rocket science, but working as a ringer is no Yellowstone. Here's what you need to know

image.altText: Pacific Island worker smiling

items.synopsis: This fruit picker is supporting his family in Vanuatu to recover from cyclones. He hopes changes to the Pacific worker program will help him send more money home.

title.children: Record number of Pacific Islanders now work in Australia helping supply your next meal

image.altText: Pat Cummins holds his arms out and looks skyward as Cam Green completes a catch in the foreground

items.synopsis: The rain came in heavy on day three at Edgbaston, but not before Australia unleashed a brief storm of its own to set up a fascinating final two days of the opening Ashes Test.

title.children: Storm clouds inspire Australia's most thrilling spell, and set up potential Edgbaston classic

image.altText: Usman Khawaja bends forward and looks back at his stumps cartwheeling

items.synopsis: Australia took two quick wickets between rain delays, Jonny Bairstow missed another catch and Moeen Ali was fined. Here's what you missed overnight at the Ashes.

title.children: Five things from day three of the Ashes: Khawaja falls into a trap and Moeen cops a fine

image.altText: A car on a race track with sparks flying underneath, with another vehicle behind with parachutes deployed

items.synopsis: Footage of the event shows the car hitting a barrier before continuing out of shot, narrowly missing a competitor's vehicle.

title.children: Driver in critical condition after car hits tyre barrier at Darwin drag race

image.altText: A road sign that says Arlparra is 250 kilometres away from Alice Springs.

items.synopsis: Police say Major Crash detectives are investigating the circumstances around the crash, north-east of Alice Springs, and have notified the Northern Territory's workplace watchdog of the incident.

title.children: Driver killed, passenger injured in Central Australia single-vehicle rollover

image.altText: A dad and mum dishing out pasta.

items.synopsis: Millions of middle-income families who believe they should be working towards a more comfortable life, are instead increasingly feeling the pinch.

title.children: The D'souzas tried out a financial advisor's best tips for saving money. Here's what they learned

image.altText: A man of Asian descent in a suit, smiling and holding a Logie award

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happen.

title.children: Logie award nominees to be announced, and a sausage dog world record is set in Melbourne. Catch up with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Nominees for the 63rd Logie Awards will be announced this morning at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Sydney — and we'll bring them to you as soon as they arrive. Comedian Sam Pang (from The Front Bar and Have You Been Paying Attention?) is hosting this year, joining the likes of previous hosts Graham Kennedy, Bert Newton, Don Lane, Andrew Denton and Shaun Micallef. The awards will be broadcast on Sunday, July 30. The Logies returned last year after a three-year absence. Hamish Blake won the Gold Logie for Most Popular Personality on Australian TV, and also took home the inaugural Bert Newton award for most popular presenter. The ABC's Tony Armstrong won the Graham Kennedy award for Most Popular New Talent.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: The 2023 Logie Award nominees are being announced this morning

children.content: Nominees for the 63rd Logie Awards
will be announced this morning at the Museum of Contemporary Art in Sydney — and we'll bring them to you as soon as they arrive.
Comedian
Sam Pang
(from The Front Bar and Have You Been Paying Attention?) is hosting this year, joining the likes of previous hosts Graham Kennedy, Bert Newton, Don Lane, Andrew Denton and Shaun Micallef.
The awards will be broadcast on
Sunday, July 30
The Logies returned last year after a three-year absence.
Hamish Blake won the Gold Logie for Most Popular Personality on Australian TV, and also took home the inaugural Bert Newton award for most popular presenter.
The ABC's Tony Armstrong won the Graham Kennedy award for Most Popular New Talent.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The United Nations say Russia has "so far declined our request to access the areas under its temporary military control" after the Kakhovka Dam burst on June 6. The burst unleashed floodwaters and cutting off supplies to civilians. "The UN will continue to engage to seek the necessary access," UN humanitarian coordinator for Ukraine, Denise Brown, says in a statement. "We urge the Russian authorities to act in accordance with their obligations under international humanitarian law. "Aid cannot be denied to people who need it."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: UN says Russia won't give access to areas affected by the Kakhovka dam burst

props.alt: An aerial image of flooding around houses

children.content: (Reuters)
The United Nations say Russia has "so far declined our request to access the areas under its temporary military control" after the Kakhovka Dam burst on June 6.
The
burst unleashed floodwaters and cutting off supplies to civilians.
"The UN will continue to engage to seek the necessary access," UN humanitarian coordinator for Ukraine, Denise Brown, says in a statement.
"We urge the Russian authorities to act in accordance with their obligations under international humanitarian law.
"Aid cannot be denied to people who need it."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Rain has ended day three of the first Ashes Test early, with England 2-28 in their second innings, leading by 35 runs. Australia's Pat Cummins made the breakthrough after a brief rain delay, leading to a catch in the gully by Cameron Green. It proved to be a profitable 20-minute session before the rain returned for Australia, when Scott Boland had Zak Crawley feathering one behind to Alex Carey to leave England 2-28. Read up on the five things we learned from day three of the first Ashes Test, below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: News Australia is searching for: Pat Cummins

featuredLink.title: Five highlights from day three of the first Ashes Test as Khawaja falls into a trap and Moeen cops a fine

children.content: Rain has ended day three of the first Ashes Test early, with
England 2-28 in their second innings
, leading by 35 runs.
Australia's
Pat Cummins made the breakthrough
after a brief rain delay, leading to a catch in the gully by Cameron Green.
It proved to be a profitable 20-minute session before the rain returned for Australia, when Scott Boland had Zak Crawley feathering one behind to Alex Carey to leave England 2-28.
Read up on the five things we learned from day three of the first Ashes Test, below:

image.altText: An Indigenous woman cooks kangaroo tails on a campfire.

items.synopsis: In remote Australia, supply chains can stretch for thousands of kilometres, which means the cost of freighting fresh food is stretching budgets to breaking point.

title.children: Why a pumpkin costs $28, a 1.25L bottle of Coke is $7, and diesel is $3.37 a litre in this community

image.altText: He stands in a dark blue shirt in front of a sign saying 'Cosmo' painted like the Aboriginal flag

items.synopsis: Sealing the 2,700-kilometre Outback Way could be good for remote artists. It could also bring more tourism, traffic, jobs and freight.

title.children: Sealing a road across inland Australia could forever change our most remote communities

image.altText: A young man with long curly hair stands next to a young woman in a doorway

items.synopsis: As rental prices climb, it's difficult to escape the number of short-stay properties around Hobart. Owners may soon be charged double rates as the council tries to limit their impact and spread.

title.children: Adam and Vienna finally found a rental, but their neighbours are becoming Airbnbs

image.altText: A man in a navy sweater stands in front of a graffiti wall smiling

items.synopsis: Dark Mofo screens controversial satire about Indigenous identity, starring a white actor.

subjects.title: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Art

image.altText: A screengrab from a video showing staff of Conservative mayoral candidate Shaun Bailey partying during lockdown.

items.synopsis: Michael Gove describes a video of a party at the Conservative Party's headquarters during a lockdown in 2020 as "terrible", as COVID rule-breaking gatherings continue to hang over the government.

title.children: 'Completely out of order': Senior UK minister says latest lockdown party video is 'terrible'

image.altText: A man uses chopsticks to rotate a hunk of meat in a frypan on an induction stovetop.

items.synopsis: Switching from gas to all-electric has significant financial and environmental benefits, but many households face hurdles that make it hard or impossible to do. Here's how governments could make it easier, writes Esther Suckling.

title.children: Switching from gas to all-electric is better for your budget and the planet

image.altText: Cassandra Dinkelman holds her son George, who has Down syndrome

items.synopsis: Life with kids means less sleep — especially for the half a million Australian children living with a neurodisability — but a new study hopes to change that.

title.children: 'It's an essential need': National study aims to improve the sleep of children with neurodisability

image.altText: A dish of meat with vegetables including brussel sprouts, presented very nicely on a plate.

items.synopsis: For decades, John and Katrina Kelly have been selling wallaby meat in Tasmania. Over that time, they say the public perception of the meat has changed dramatically.

title.children: From 'pet food' to 'fine food', a Tasmanian couple's 30-year effort to change attitudes to wallaby meat

image.altText: A smiling young girl in headshot

items.synopsis: More than two years after Aishwarya Aswath died at Perth Children's Hospital, new nursing staff-to-patient ratios are set to take effect to improve safety, but there are concerns over where the extra staff will come from.

title.children: Two years after Aishwarya died in Perth hospital, new staff ratios are set to take effect — but concerns remain

image.altText: Relatives attend to a patient lying on a stretcher in the premises of a hospital in India.

items.synopsis: At least 96 people die in two of India's most populous states over the last several days, with swaths of the country reeling from a heatwave.

title.children: Nearly 100 die as India battles sweltering heatwave

image.altText: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken walks with Chinese Foreign Minister Qin Gang.

items.synopsis: In the landmark meeting, the US Secretary of State and Chinese Foreign Minister held talks on their differences from Taiwan to trade, but seemed to agree on little beyond keeping the conversation going with an eventual meeting in Washington.

title.children: Taiwan top issue as Blinken meets China's foreign minister

image.altText: A visor-wearing female tennis player roars in triumph after winning a US Open title.

items.synopsis: The 2021 win came with praise but also exposed the then-18-year-old to a previously unknown world of instant fame, often ruthless and paved with expectations.

title.children: Emma Raducanu says she wishes she'd 'never won the US Open' amid pressures of fame, injury

image.altText: Max Verstappen in his navy blue F1 car, turns through a corner as he races, with one car chasing behind.

items.synopsis: The Dutchman was flawless in Montreal, never looking threatened as he took his 41st career win.

title.children: Verstappen draws level with F1 legend, Red Bull takes 100th victory

image.altText: Bridget McKenzie stands in a courtyard surrounded by journalists and microphones

items.synopsis: Coalition frontbencher Bridget McKenzie backs independent senator Lidia Thorpe's use of parliamentary privilege to detail allegations of sexual harassment at Parliament House.

title.children: Bridget McKenzie rebukes Barnaby Joyce, backs Lidia Thorpe for using Senate to raise allegations

image.altText: Marine Rescue vessels  on the water involved in search for missing spear fisherman on the NSW south coast

items.synopsis: A spear fisherman who spent the night on a remote island in the Beowa National Park has been found safe and well on day two of the search.

title.children: Relief and elation as missing diver found after spending night on remote NSW island

image.altText: Boxer Tim Tszyu smiles at the camera, with fists clenched and a world title belt slun over his shoulder.

items.synopsis: Australian boxer Tim Tszyu knocks out Mexican Carlos Ocampo in the most impressive win of his career to retain the WBO super-welterweight world title.

title.children: 77 seconds of mayhem — Tim Tszyu finishes world interim title bout in half a round

image.altText: Aerial shot of giant floating gas plant

items.synopsis: Off Australia's north coast, two of the world's energy titans are entwined in a fierce duel. How it came to pass is as much a story about corporate egos as it is flawed strategies.

image.altText: Smoke comes out from Philippine ferry as it caught fire at the waters off Panglao, Bohol province, central Philippines.

items.synopsis: Maritime accidents are common in the Philippines due to weather and poor safety regulations in the country's remote regions.

title.children: Philippine ferry carrying 120 passengers catches fire at sea

image.altText: Garbin takes the ball with both hands

items.synopsis: Australia have named their 2023 Netball World Cup squad for Cape Town and head coach Stacey Marinkovich has made some big calls, as the Diamonds look to win back the crown New Zealand pinched from them four years ago.

title.children: Sophie Garbin makes the Netball World Cup team and Ash Brazill gets a Diamonds send-off after Pies season from hell
